Treasury and Internal Revenue Service agents yesterday raided the South Carolina headquarters of J. K. Harris Inc., the nation's largest company helping people settle back tax debts at a discount.
The company represents 18,000 individuals and small business through a network of 350 offices.
About 20 agents arrived in the North Charleston offices with a large truck to take away records.
The company sent about 150 employees at three offices in two buildings home for the day, said John K. Harris, the company president.

''Our size and success in representing'' people before the I.R.S., Mr. Harris said, ''has also made us a target by the I.R.S., as well as certain competitors. We are cooperating fully with the government.''

Mr. Harris said the subpoena was for documents bearing his signature that allow him to represent taxpayers before the I.R.S. as a certified public accountant. Mr. Harris has surrendered his license as a certified public accountant in two states.
The raid included agents from both the Treasury inspector general for tax administration and the I.R.S. criminal investigation division.
Mr. Harris said that he first learned his firm was under investigation six weeks ago.
